bibl.author: James W. Wallace
bibl.title: James W. Wallace to Walt Whitman, 10 February 1891
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: Just a few lines in acknowledgment of your very kind and affectionate post card of Jan: 27th, addressed to Dr Johnston, & received yesterday.

It's Its most important sentence, to us, is that referring to yourself. (I continue rather poorly. End uncertain)
And we shall be very anxious indeed till we hear further & better news. I do hope that you are better by this time, & am looking forward to the receipt of a message from Traubel.

I got today a copy of this month's "Magazine of Art," which I will send on to you with this. It contains some additional & later portraits
of Ruskin, which will perhaps interest you. But the writer has to end by saying that Ruskin's "portrait—his true portrait—does not exist. It could not exist."
I wish I could send you something more but must content myself, for the present, with saying that our loving sympathy & best wishes are with you always.
